issue.title: fix: getTag return incorrect tag, if we have more than 1 tag for 1 commit

body: had to revert #1164, will need to find another fix for this.

issue.title: goreleaser fails because of alphabetical tag sort
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

If there are old tags that start with the letter 'y' or 'z', goreleaser will fail with this error. 
```
release failed after 0.10s error=git tag y-tag was not made against commit <latest-commit>
```
goreleaser enforces semver, so normally all newer tags will start with the letter 'v' or with a number. Thus it will always be alphabetically sorted below those tags. 

Further more if we have tags like v0.0.1 and then 0.0.2(without the 'v' in the tag), alphabetically v0.0.1 will be first. Both are valid semvers

**To Reproduce**

Create a tag starting with letter 'y' or 'z'. In latter commits, create tags with semver. Run `goreleaser release`.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**

- OS: mac
- OS version: Darwin Ninan-2.local 18.6.0 Darwin Kernel Version 18.6.0: Thu Apr 25 23:16:27 PDT 2019; root:xnu-4903.261.4~2/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64
- GoReleaser Version: 0.120.1


Additional Notes:

This is becaue of the addition of `-c versionsort.suffix=- tag -l --sort=-v:refname` in the process of finding latest tag.

body: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

issue.title: Allow specifying which tag to build
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
We currently have our CLI inside a monorepo with the server. Our deploy process creates tags associated with the environment (eg. `prod-timestamp`). We are using semantic version tags for releasing the CLI. 
We've run into issues where the commit has already been tagged with the environment. Tagging the commit with a semantic version (eg. `v0.3.2`) causes GitHub Actions to run goreleaser. However, goreleaser picks the environment tag and fails because it's not a semantic version.
It looks like this issue has been raised before: #1163.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A few options are:
- Allow setting which tag to build using an environment variable, like `GORELEASER_TAG`.
- Allow specifying a custom [`getTag()`](https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/blob/449ed95bbe73fb88159e061352fcc786987d7d7d/internal/pipe/git/git.go#L124-L126) command. 
  - Then we could use `git describe --tags --match "v*" --abbrev=0` to pick the semantic version tag.
- Swapping to `git describe --tags --match "v*" --abbrev=0` to pick the tag. 
  - However, that would break users who don't prefix with `v`. 
    - Though maybe there could be an environment variable or setting to enable that mode, (eg. `GORELEASER_ENABLE_V_SEMVAR=true`? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇ)
    - Or if `git describe --tags --match "v*" --abbrev=0` doesn't yield a tag, we fallback to the current command.
      - However, that wouldn't work if someone started using `v*` tags, but later dropped the prefix.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
We currently have a bash script to loop through all the local tags and delete them until it reaches one that matches `v*`. While that works, it feels a bit hacky.

**Additional context**
I'm willing to help implement this if there's interest.

body: Could this be re-opened as this issue still persists?

Would it be possible to just rely on the CI information when it's available, e.g. `CIRCLE_TAG`? Sometimes we need to bump versions which don't necessarily have any changes because we keep versions of multiple projects in step. Because of this bug, we always have to create a dummy commit in order to be able to build the binaries using goreleaser, which is quite annoying and git history polluting :/

issue.title: Use CI environment variables to figure out tag
issue.body:
This patch detects CI environments and uses the available tag information when
collecting the git tag.

This resolves issues where one commit has multiple tags.

Closes #1163
Closes #1311

body: I commented my thoughts on the PR, but generally I think it should be OK yes! :)
This issue has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
